title: Spring mansion hunters emerge from hibernation
text:
Nearby on Canberra's "Golden Mile", a five-bedroom English Manor-style home has just hit the market with price expectations in the mid-$5 million range.

Selling agent Mario Sanfrancesco said uncertainty around the federal election earlier this year followed by winter had dampened activity at the upper end of the market, but both sellers and buyers were starting to re-emerge with renewed confidence.

"We've seen just in recent weeks, that that's starting to change," Mr Sanfrancesco said. "There's some buyers that had been sitting on the sidelines that have now made a decision and there's been a couple of properties that have changed hands recently."

Sydney: 111 Victoria Road in Bellevue Hill sold for $10.1 million, well above price expectations.

In Sydney, $5 million-plus houses that would normally be earmarked for a more discreet expressions-of-interest campaign are being taken to auction to make the most of the heightened competition.

Over the weekend a grand seven-bedroom house on Victoria Road in Bellevue Hill sold under the hammer for $10.1 million, with six bidders pushing the price well above the $8 million price guide and opening bid of $7 million. It last sold in 1983 for $770,000.

According to buyers' agent Rodney McLoughlin, Sydney buyers were fighting over properties within a 10 kilometre radius of the CBD that were priced anywhere between $1.5 million and $10 million.

Advertisement

"It's got absolutely crazy," he said. "People are fighting for properties and are missing out on properties left, right and centre."

Raine & Horne's Peter Starr, who sold the Bellevue Hill property under the hammer, has also chosen to take a four-bedroom harbourfront home at Kurraba Point to auction next month given competition is heating up.

"Good properties are hard to price at the moment and in any market the buyers dictate the price, not the sellers, so you don't want to get caught short by not exposing it to the full market," Mr Starr said.

Victoria: 1 Stonnington Place in Toorak sold well above the reserve price.

"With 111 Victoria Road, the underbidder pushed himself more than $1 million more than I think he would have otherwise been willing to pay in a pre-auction situation. He needed to see the competition to know he wasn't doing the wrong thing."

In Melbourne, a three-bedroom house on 590sq m at 1 Stonnington Place in Toorak ended up in a boardroom auction on Saturday evening, with a reserve of $5 million. It sold for $6.005 million.

"Anything good is going through the roof. And if it's not, it's either overpriced or it's a lemon," Melbourne buyers' agent David Morrell said.

Kay & Burton's Robert Fletcher and Michael Gibson would not comment on the sale but said heightened competition in the market meant the "price point opportunity of an auction is climbing".
description: Idyllic spring weather combined with record low interest rates and renewed market confidence has kickstarted the top-end property market.
